title: Why isn't every chess game between the top players the same set of moves? Isn't there a 'best' set of moves? - Quora

response.answer_text: There IS a best set of chess moves, or multiple sets with the same result, but we are not so close to finding it in a way that includes all possibilities/variations. For many, this failure on our part so far actually keeps chess interesting; others may continue to find chess interesting even after it is solved in the way that Connect Four and checkers have been solved. The issue of the total number of possible chess games has probably been addressed here on Quora before; one number that gets kicked around is 10^120, which indicates the massive difficulty for a complete chess algorithm. My guess is that a public announcement that chess is solved will occur well before every single variation has been worked out to its final result. Many variations not fully analyzed will simply be dismissed as trivial, and some (nit-pickers?) will hold out and deny the completeness of the proposed solution. In any case, perhaps you already know that many games between top-level players actually DO follow the same “main line” moves for quite a while (e.g. very often beyond move 10, sometimes beyond move 20), but even those games usually break off to different lines, for at least two reasons: #1. At least one of the players doesn’t know what the “best” move is beyond a certain point; and #2. even if both players know what is theoretically “best,” it may lead to a draw with best play from there, so a player who needs (or just really wants) to win might want to “muddy the waters” by playing a non-best move that puts both players on their own resources. There may be an issue as to whether or not chess is a draw with best play by both sides. If it IS a draw with best play, then for purposes of your question, the next issue is whether or not there is more than one line that draws (for example, perhaps both 1. d4 and 1. e4 both draw against the best defense). In my opinion, this is the most likely possibility, and it would answer your question in terms of there already being two different “best” lines. But even if chess has only one forced drawing line for White (unlikely in my opinion), then people would need to know it before the top players can execute it all the way. On the other hand, if chess is a win for White, then again we would need to know if more than one line wins for White. If so, then again your question would be answered in terms of two different “best” winning lines. I believe that the overall approach to solving chess is to go ‘forward’ with opening theory while continuing to work ‘backward’ (retrograde analysis) with endgame tablebases. The latter are 100% accurate, and have been worked out to all positions with at least 7 pieces, and maybe at least 8. If and when THAT work is completed, then what your question raises may actually happen. But it’s also possible that at such a point, people may lose interest in chess as a serious competitive endeavor.

There is a problem with identifying the “best” move statistically, and no player would just memorize the line of “best” moves…not even using something that appears impartial like a winning percentage. The mental effort required to memorize best moves is insane, and unproductive. One move from the “second or third best” list, and all your memorization would be trashed.You know nothing about the “winning percentage” associated with a particular move. Many moves are very common among even high rated players, but known by one or two champion players to be refuted. You don’t know how often that move was played only against lower rated players.A move that an aggressive player would LOVE might be a move that a solid or conservative positional player would never play in a lifetime. Some moves might suit an endgame specialist beautifully and be scorned by the “trappy” or “combination” oriented player.Just because a move has a good winning percentage doesn’t tell you ANYTHING about the strategy that move is designed to execute. If you are not following the same strategy then there’s no need to “pin the knight” … or whatever that move is. Your moves should come out of your strategy…not picked out of a list of “best” on some database.Better (and more fun) to play your own game and learn how to play the best you can without trying to memorize a decision tree.
